module.p:
The English word if has two main uses:
introducing a conditional-hypothetical subordinate clause
introducing an embedded question.

Here are some examples of if being used to introduce a conditional-hypothetical clause:
“I won’t take you to the police if you do a bit of work for me.”
“If you stopped paying that, he would come to his senses.”
“If you don't do that, it certainly won’t be me who comes to see you.”

Note that the word if can be (somewhat clumsily) rephrased using ‘assuming that’ in these examples:
“I won’t take you to the police assuming that you do a bit of work for me.”
“Assuming that you stopped paying that, he would come to his senses.”
“Assuming that you don't do that, it certainly won’t be me who comes to see you.”

Here are some examples of the second use of the word if, introducing an embedded question:
He asked if Maggie was in.
He asked if Maggie wasn’t in.

The word if can be easily replaced by ‘whether’ in these examples:
He asked whether Maggie was in.
He asked whether Maggie wasn’t in.

Or the whole embedded question could be turned into reported speech:
He asked, “Is Maggie in?”
He asked, “Is Maggie not in?”

When if is used in a conditional-hypothetical sense, it corresponds to one of the following Gaelic subordinating conjunctions:
ma ‘if’
mura ‘if not’, ‘unless’
nan ‘if’

For example:
“Cha toir mi gu lagh thu ma nì thu car obrach dhòmhsa.”
“I won’t take you to the police if you do a bit of work for me.” [#2 29]
“Nan sguireadh tu a phàigheadh sin, thigeadh e gu chiall.”
“If you stopped paying that, he would come to his senses.” [#2 7]
“Mura dèan thu sin, chan e mise a thig a choimhead ort idir.”
“If you don't do that, it certainly won’t be me who comes to see you.” [#2: 55]

When if is used to introduce an embedded question, it corresponds to embedded uses of the Gaelic interrogative verb particles:
an
nach

For example:
Dh’fhaighnich e an robh Magaidh a-staigh.
‘He asked if Maggie was in.’ [#2 124]
Dh’fhaighnich e nach robh Magaidh a-staigh.
‘He asked if Maggie wasn’t in.’

Note that using ma or nan to introduce an embedded question is ☠️ Beurlachas ☠️:
☠️ Dh’fhaighnich e ma bha Magaidh a-staigh. ☠️
☠️ Dh’fhaighnich e nan robh Magaidh a-staigh. ☠️
